Could it be the rotating mass of the rock?
As the rock moves down the ice with a clockwise rotation the mass on the left wants to keep moving in a forward direction, while the mass on the right wants to move opposite to the forward direction. The masses at the front and the rear of the rock cancel each other.
This can be tested by placing a giro with the same mass as the rock on a frame mounted on four rocks.
The only force that would curl the setup as it slides down the ice would be the rotation of the spinning mass.

In my own thought experiment, I agree with the latter demonstration. It appears to be sort of the "reverse of Bernoulli's principle". When the rock is thrown with a twist, one side is spinning faster than the other. The faster side therefore also covers more rotational distance than the other, in this case, creating more heat to liquefy and lubricate the ice, while the less-lubed side causes drag thus pulling the stone in the direction of the drag.

Dead simple: Differential slip velocity on the ice due to the stone's rotation, affects friction with the ice on the left and right side of the stone:

To walk on ice you need traction. You have traction when you operate in or near the static friction regime. If your shoe's slip velocity is above a certain speed, all traction is lost. This is partially due to your shoe sole climbing a water wedge and being fully lubricated as a result. But is starts with the difference between static and dynamic friction - that differential is huge for ice.

As the stones spin, one side has a higher slip velocity. This while the other side has a low or zero slip velocity (when equal to the forward speed of the stone). The side with the lower slip velocity grips more, and the stone curves towards that side.

There is a related effect that limits the forward speed of a conventional helicopter. Half the blade disc has increased lift due to forward motion of the helicopter; and the other reduced lift. This lift differential is balanced out in practice, by using differential blade pitch; achieved via the swash plate. But, when the blade pitch on the trailing edge of the blade is too steep, it reaches its limit for lift to drag ratio. This occurs at the maximum forward speed of the helicopter, at a given carrying load. The Osprey avoids this by turning the lifting rotors into forward propellers for much faster cruising flight, than it could achieve in "helicopter mode".

Canadian here. Curling was my high school sport, so I find this topic fascinating. I remember we would find that a slow rotation worked much better than a fast rotation. In fact, if you wanted to ensure a straight throw (in practice only, you’d never rely on this in competition) you could spin the stone really quickly. To me, this lends credence to the theory of the differential speed of advancement melting the ice more on the left (for in-turn or right for out-turn) edge of the running band. When you spin the stone so quickly, the extra rotation overwhelmed any advantage created by the differential so the frictional lateral forces were negligible. (I think that makes sense, right?) In addition to all that is outlined here, brush head materials etc also play a big role. In more recent years, there is even directional sweeping being used. It used to be thought that sweeping simply increased distance while lessening curl and visa versa, but it turns out the direction the sweeper closest to the stone is "pushing" while sweeping can also increase or decrease curl, even while simultaneously increasing distance.

I think the curling stone moves opposite it's rotation is because the melted water molecules act like gearing in between the two surfaces. If you put two big gears together they spin opposite, but if you put a small gear between them they spin together. I think the water molecule interaction is akin to adding a small gear, so the overall net effect is equal and opposite. making the stone's path equally mirrored to it's expected Newtonian path.

Okay, Destin. Here is my theory to add to the research of the two others:

So we know that the leading edge of the curling stone hits freshly brushed pebbles of ice, as pristine as possible. The brushing of the ice in addition to the compression of the stone itself melts a tiny amount of ice into water, similar to an ice skate blade, which immediately refreezes after the leading edge has passed. The refrozen water will now have filled some scratches and valleys in between the pebbles.

The pebbles are also quite possible measurably more flattened (read: shorter) by the time the trailing edge arrives, although you might need a laser to measure the tiny difference.

The result? There is significantly more surface area on the trailing edge. Also, the trailing edge has no immediate benefit from brushing, so again, more friction than the leading edge.

More friction than the leading edge makes the stone curl in the trailing edge direction.




One more thing, the side edges of the stone should not be ignored. The edge that approaches the leading edge has more velocity than the side approaching the trailing edge. Faster speed across the ice can mean less drag while the slower side edge will have more, influencing the stone to move in that direction.

Here's a simple idea: a rotating curling stone is a model for a gyroscope. Like an ideal gyroscope or top, it tends to maintain its axis of rotation at some small angle from the vertical (ignoring precession and nutation, since the mass of the stone is large relative to its motion). Since the rotational axis of the stone is away from the vertical, friction against the ice is greater on one side of the stone, at a fixed angle when looking downward at the stone. This increased friction would obviously curve the path of the stone away from a straight line, like a stone that has more mass on one lateral side than the other.

Now, all that remains is working out the math to prove this. I think it is clear that this gyroscopic explanation could be expected to have a much larger effect than the effects of microscopic scratches, according to any of the three theories presented in this video.

I think the true explanation is much simpler. The glass curls opposite to the the spin because the weight of the glass leans forward slightly and the friction at the front is stronger than the friction at the rear. This is kinetic friction which is proportional to the contact force. On ice, it is no longer dominated by kinetic friction. You have ice that melts and air resistance causing fluid friction. Fluid friction is proportional to the square of the speed. If the rock is spinning counter-clockwise then the right side (top view ) has more friction than the left side. This causes the rock to want to expand but tensile forces in the rock keep it to together and this exerts a leftward force on the center of mass. The leftward force is a result of the right side decelerating faster than the left side as it slows and rotates. This causes the left side of the rock to push in on the center of mass more than the right side.

I wonder if the side edges play a factor in direction because of how they contact the ice with a forwards and backwards direction. The side edge which is rotating forwards has to smash through a lot of untouched ice flowing against it, the side where it’s rotating backwards is simply encouraged in its spin. It seems to me that the side of the stone moving forwards would produce more drag on that side of the stone because it’s spinning against the ice, whereas the reverse-spin side is accelerated by the ice moving in the direction of its rotation. Maybe it moves towards the direction of least resistance. At first thought it seems like it would behave like a tank turning, it moves towards the slower tread(side moving forwards) But maybe since it is spinning, it doesn’t have a stationary “tread” to slow towards, it becomes more difficult for it to move TOWARDS the rough ice on the forwards rotating side, it doesn’t want to break against that ice and it’s pushed away from it and it becomes easier for it to delve into the side moving with the ice. Kind of like climb-milling in a CNC vs conventional milling. Assuming the stone is sitting perfectly level and balanced, aside from extremely small unavoidable influences of stone imperfections, The front and back of the stone should equalize each other’s sideways forces and not influence it much, one is pushing left, one is pushing right, as far as the leading and trailing edges are concerned, it is just spinning in place in equilibrium. Granted, the leading/front edge does have to deal with rougher ice than the trailing edge of the stone at any given time of motion 🤔 I think it’s just easier for it to be pulled into the ice which is moving the same direction

I always thought it was a kind of friction difference between the two states of the water/ice: liquid and solid. The rotating rock is creating friction and thus heat melting the ice and creating a lubricant. One side is creating more friction relative to the ice because of rotational speed. Therefore the one side is creating more lubrication with the melted ice while the other gets a little more friction and drag causing the whole rock to veer. Same issue with helicopter blades generating lift at high forward speeds.

A controlled experiment for this is to increase the rotation speeds of the rock and view the results. You'll probably notice a point where a faster rotating rock goes almost as straight as an unrotating rock. Which kind of makes sense with sweeping too, if the point of sweeping is heat the ice up. Destin mentioned that sweeping causes the rock to travel further because the ice melted more.

BMW holds a vehicle control training course on the Yukon river every winter, and they discovered an interesting phenomenon that can be applied to this conundrum.


They found that, on ice, if one's car loses control, and is about to hit another vehicle, one can lock the brakes (pump the brakes once in an ABS-equipped car to defeat the ABS), turn the wheels hard in the direction one wishes to go to avoid hitting, then at the last second release the brakes: the steer tires will "bite" into the ice, begin rolling (instead of sliding), and actually steer the car in the desired direction. While locked and sliding, the tires will not only generate that layer of water between them & the ice, but they will also heat up slightly; when the brake is released, the heat in the tire will allow it to "bite" into the ice & start it rolling again, giving the car directional control again. And, yes: it works.


This is similar to what's happening with curling stones: the forward-spinning edge of the contact ring is generating a fractional heating event that creates the water layer between the ring and the ice; and that self-same heating is allowing the rearward-spinning edge to "bite" into the ice and create that moment force that pushes the stone in the desired direction.


I'm not sure if the "micro-scratch" theory is valid, since we're talking about microscopic scratches over a VERY small area of ice (the test is VERY exaggerated), but it might lend a fractional amount of forces into the event.



Also, no one's looked at the precessional effects of a spinning rock on ice. Something to consider.

Well since this video is about theories, here is mine. For a while now we have seen how traction control and ABS (antilock braking system) works on cars. The principle is that you increase friction between the two surfaces, ie. Road and tires, by reducing the resistance or the opposing force if you will, between the two. Since there is a fine line between maximum grip and none at all, and this applies especially to ice. So when driving on snow or ice, applying more power ultimately reduces friction due to the surface melting. So the onboard computer now has to allow the wheels to spin slightly while braking to stay at maximum friction with as little surface melting as possible or optimally none at all. The opposite is also true when trying to move on ice or snow. The conputer will send much less power to the driving wheels to prevent spinning and stay within the grip provided by the elasticity and usable surface area of the rubber. This leads me to believe then, that the retreating side is spinning slow enough to grip the ice, while the advancing side is moving too fast to be affected by friction, so the rock will lose velocity on the retreating side and curl in that direction. Think of it as the inside having abs, and the outside skidding because the wheels locked up. I hope that makes sense, and I also believe that ice is a key factor. The rock would not behave the same on glass, water, wood or any other surface. I've only ever seen this form of traction on ice (yes that includes snow).

We need a $100M DARPA grant and a supercomputer to run some thorough tests, and maybe we'll get a better idea.
As for the nations who spend the most of research having better teams, that isn't really conclusive; it may be that those nations are just more into curling, and that's why they are both good at it and why they are willing to spend the money to research it. Doesn't necessarily mean that research = better performance. If it turned out that Canada spent more money on researching hockey than the US, that wouldn't necessarily mean that the research is the REASON they are better at hockey, it would just mean that Canadians love hockey more than the US does, and therefore their better athletes end up becoming hockey players instead of basketball players, AND that there would be more public interest and support in providing government funding to retain their edge. Gyroscopic forces could account for the direction of curl. With the glass, as it is decelerating, the front area of contact has more drag, which combined with the rapid spin of the glass pushes it in the opposite direction of the spin. But a curling stone has much greater mass, which alows gyroscopic force to take a much bigger role. The stone wants to tip forward during deceleration, but gyroscopically the force is applied 90 degrees "downspin". This causes greater drag on that side of the stone, which in turn causes the stone to curl in that direction. I expect that the balance between  the pure-spin drag and the gyroscopic drag is very sensitive to the coefficient of friction of the ice, hence the pebbling to maximize the effect. How does curl on smooth ice compare to curl on pebbled ice?

Thank you very much - fascinating. One question though, why doesn’t anyone mention the phenomenon of regulation? This is where ice meals simply due to there being pressure exerted on it. As a student I remember seeing a block of ice with a length of copper wire across the top and two heavy masses hung from either end of the wire. Over time the wire cut its way through the ice - the explanation being that regulation was melting a thin slice of the ice which allowed the wire to drop which in turn started to melt the fresh ice that the wire was now in contact with. In addition, due to the latent heat capacity of the ice, the small amount of frozen water above the wire then refrozen. This phenomenon, regulation, is also why ice skating works so well - the weight of the skaters presses on the ice and slightly melts a thin layer. So, surely regulation plays a part in the movement of something as large as these stones which I think are around 32lb.?

At the risk of sounding arrogant (or possibly dumb), I'd like to submit my theory..  I believe they have both missed the mark,.. it is all about momentum, (and a little friction) especially momentum on ice. Much like a vehicle taking a curve on ice where the rear and outside curve momentum of the vehicle pushes past the front and inside curve of the vehicle causing a spin in the direction of the curve (if it is a leftward curve it will be a counterclockwise spin), also while entering this leading edge of the vehicle encounters more friction than the following edge of the vehicle, which then causes this tipping effect (forward edge meeting more friction causing a gripping downward momentum thus causing a shift of weight lifting the rear edge of the object thus reducing the rear outward friction further. Likewise the spin of the curling stone when pushed is causing a greater momentum on the outer spin side of the stone. That higher momentum, for example on a clockwise spinning stone the higher momentum being from the 8 o'clock to the 12 o'clock positions, and the lesser momentum being from around the 3 o'clock to 5 o'clock positions and the areas in between being more or less neutral, "curls" the stone in that direction. So picture a momentum arrow going form the 8 o'clock to 12 o'clock position and the momentum of the weight of the stone will carry or push the stone in that direction, to the right. The spin generated at the stone's release will also generate a slight "tipping" motion from that momentum causing the stone to tilt toward its inner lower momentum side causing an increase in friction on that side while lifting and reducing friction on the outer higher momentum side therefore increasing the momentum and direction of the "curl" further in the direction of momentum.  The outcome is much different with the experiment of a glass on wood surface due to the much higher effects of friction on surfaces other than ice.

A big part of melting isn't friction melting, it's pressure melting.

Ice is bigger when it's frozen. If you pressurize it, you can force it back into the liquid state. When you press on ice with something heavy, like a skater with ice skates or a heavy curling stone, you get pressure melting, even though the ice is still below the freezing point.

When I began curling 12 years ago (I'm only 20 so it's been a big part of my life), I originally thought it was the same thing as the guy from BC said. I'm also Canadian, so maybe that's just how we think. The scratch theory that the Swedish man talked about is what we used for so-called Directional Sweeping. If a sweeper starts their broom in front of the centre of the rock and sweeps on a slight angle towards the other side of the rock, they will create scratches on the ice like the Swedish experiment with the sandpaper. This will cause the rock to tend towards that direction. Before 2010, sweeping was mainly to make the rock go further, and also to make it curl less. Now, when I say curl less, there's an important distinction to be made. The rock is not actually curling less. If you throw two rocks 100% exactly the same, one swept and one not, the two rocks will line up perfectly, just one past the other. The rock doesn't curl less, but more it delays its "breaking point" when it really starts to curl, due to it not losing as much speed because of the sweeping. Before the 2010 Vancouver Olympics, we in Canada did a study on sweeping and figured out all this stuff about directional sweeping, but it wasn't really used. In 2013 and 2014, we had what would later be called the "Broom-ha-ha." Horsehair brooms, as can be seen at 4:22 with the guy on the right in the video, are extremely efficient at this directional sweeping, because the individual hairs scratch the ice a ton, and therefore make the rock move a ton. An interesting video on it can be found here: https://youtu.be/haEuz42YCdM The scratches in the ice make the rock tend towards a direction, but I don't think the rock causes the scratches enough to make it curl. I believe that it's the difference in velocities on the sides of the running band that cause it to curl.

A development at the Semi-pro/Olympic levels* in the last few years since the video was made is directional sweeping. It's been so dramatic that the governing body for the sport has started regulating the fabrics used as the sweeping surface on the brooms to have a consistent friction, rather than a variable teams can play with. Think different grit levels in sandpaper.

Essentially your stroke in sweeping the rock will be stronger on motion pushing away from you than pulling back, and you will induce curl in the push direction. You see near equal amounts of one person sweeping for this purpose than both trying to take the rock further. You will see this in action if you watch the 2018 Olympics.

*There is a semi-pro tour in Canada with nationally televised games. Most are Canadians, but a few countries like Sweden and Scotland send over their national team. It's stiffer competition than the Olympics. Most semi-pro teams are the best teams Canadian teams around who compete in an open national championship.

I often see when curling is explained quickly the explanation "the goal is to get your team's rocks closest to the button" -- and while this is true it's kind of misleading. Because then people might see each thrown rock as an attempt to get close to the button, which isn't the case at all. It's not like darts of bowling in that sense - the goal is for at the end of the 'end', if you have last rock, to have at least two of your rocks closer to the button than all of the other team's rocks, and if you don't have the hammer, to either force the other team to only score one point (giving you the hammer for the next end) or 'steal' by actually scoring points when your team doesn't have last rock. It's not like every player is trying to get their rock closer to the button, not at all actually. They'll be playing some sort of strategy to make it so that when all the rocks are thrown, they end up with closer rocks. Which means most of the stones they throw will be placed strategically to allow for that, not just get close to the button.

They were able to make the rock curl more, and even curl NEGATIVELY backward (sideways, not slow down), while still having rotation! 1) The glass has a high center of gravity, vs the low center of gravity for the curling stone.
2) The side with the higher difference in speed between the stone and the ice, will be further from gripping, so will experience less friction.
As a bonus, the glass has a higher surface area compared to its mass.

Yeah I understand the second theory better. And this is why. I've got a little over three years flying the Alaska Bush at different times in my life. The first I was there the 1984 -85. One of the villages that I flew into to. Could only be done in the the winter, because the village had no runway and was split by a narrow river. So after the river froze sufficiently thick. They would set up cones and put up a Winsock. Now the first time I went there I was told that if you wanted to make a right turn you hit the left brake. So that's what I did. To my amazement it worked very well. It just really hard to push the right rudder pedal all the way to the stops. To turn the rudder the correct way. But then use the left brake and not the right. Which goes totally against your training. The reason it works that way was because the rolling tire created more friction and therefore made more drag on the right side. While the left tire being stopped actually created less drag. Because the ice was melting under it reducing the friction.Which then help the nose wheel steering to the right.
And when you got really good you can lock up both tires and drift. As long as the ice was glass smooth.

You can often see something similar when a stone comes to rest. One point on the stone will reach 0 speed and stone will pivot about that point. That point has maximum friction. Yes, that thin layer of lubricating water refreezes that fast. So without the lubricatiing layer at that small point, there is enough friction to spin the entire rock, much like a death spiral in figure skating.

Also, as a rock slows, it curls more. I think that supports the Canadian theory a little better than the Swedish.

I would think that angular momentum would have some impact on the direction of each object, no?  The glass spins very quickly, relative to its diameter.  The stone, however, has a contact surface much smaller in diameter than the diameter of the object and it is spinning much, much slower.  Sometimes not even one full rotation before it stops.

So, then, wouldn't the forward momentum overpower the angular momentum's effect? If forward momentum is not perfectly straight, than as it overpowers the effect of angular momentum it will move in the direction the stone was pushed, regardless of spin.

Notice with the glass that it doesn't really start to curve off course until its forward momentum slows, while the angular momentum stays fairly constant.  It isn't until its forward momentum is less than the effect of the rotation that it begins to move off course.  I theorize that it moves opposite of the spin because the angular momentum overpowers the forward momentum.

As for the curling stone, forward momentum is maintained all the way through and appears to always be greater than its angular momentum, even right before it stops.

I'm curious to see what would happen if you spun that stone as fast as you could while pushing it forward relatively slowly.  Perhaps then the angular momentum would overpower the forward momentum and we'd see it move just like the glass does due to friction at the front being greater than at the rear.

The bottom of the stone interacting with the ice might be 10-15% but the real factor is the weight and mass of the object. Centrifugal force while traveling in a fixed direction will cause the object to move in that direction thus if the stone is heavy and the friction is very low the weight of the stone spinning is causing the sideways rotation in travel. The reason your glass won't on the table is because the friction of the table and glass together is way to much for how heavy the glass is. It's simple math that I learned in 10th grade. Think about a tire on a car the top of the tire is moving faster (relative to the ground/earth) than the bottom so it's centrifugal force is different on top than bottom, if you could stand on that tire as it was rolling around and moving in a set direction you would not only speed up and slow down as you went around you would also be getting lighter and heavier as the speed changes the centrifugal force. So the point at which you get lighter is were the weight/mass is being forced in that direction more that the opposite direction.
Don't forget that simple pressure also melts ice. Nothing to do with friction. Not much friction on an ice skate but plenty of pressure.

Love it, Destin.  Thanks so much for a great analysis and vid.  You're the science guy, so please set me straight.  At 3:01 you highlight deceleration--on board with ya.  At 4:39 you mention that the swept stone would go straighter and farther--yep.  But at 4:55 you start talking about the lubrication barrier and say that it "reduc[es] the friction" and "allow[s] the stone to travel farther and faster".  Although we curlers say that the ice gets "faster" when the stone travels longer and farther, it seems to me that you're suggesting an increase in the velocity (faster) of the already delivered stone, something that shouldn't be possible since there is no longer any applied, external force.  BTW, to add some details for you, there are over 20 sizes of pebble heads, i.e. more than 20 combinations of differently sized holes and different numbers of holes.  In some tournaments it helps to maintain consistency when two are used so that as the larger pebble wears down with play there's a smaller, fresher pebble ready to go.  I look forward to your thoughts, and thanks again.

The second theory totally explains it, and I'm not just saying that because I'm Canadian. It makes sense on so many levels. It's all about sliding vs static friction and friction melting, They pebble the ice to increase friction melting and sweeping further enhances that effect. Sweeping doesn't just reduce the curl but makes it go straighter, as was said (why would that be the case with the scratch theory?). Also spinning the stone too fast (say one revolution every 3m) causes it to go straight and long. Points of low friction won't have anything to do with the curl, it is the points of high friction (and low velocity) that "grab" the stone and cause it to pivot. I think that specifically the water "transport theory" makes the most sense, and the magic spot would be between the receding side and the trailing side, where there is high friction plus a transverse force. When a stone is finally coming to a stop it often does a major pivot right around that area.

I've always subscribed to a much simpler asymmetric friction melting theory than what you've described: the advancing side of the rock (left when viewed from behind for a clockwise-spinning stone) generates more friction melting than the retreating side, as you said, but the effect of this is not necessarily anything more than that the advancing side has less friction than the retreating side, so the vector of the net frictional force on the rock, while straight backwards, passes to the side of its centre of mass, so the rock turns towards the retreating side. This laterally off-centre friction force is the same thing that causes a shopping cart entering an area of a higher-friction ground at an angle to turn towards the side whose wheel entered the new area first, or a wave entering a medium of slower transmission speed to refract towards the normal.

However, one troubling fact is that when you first start curling on fresh (i.e. unscratched) ice, the rock does not go as far. As the game continues through the first two ends the ice gets faster, then normally stabilizes for the rest of the game, sometimes getting a bit slower at the end.

If the ice is getting scratched all the time, and this increases friction, then the ice should slow down as the game progresses.

I'm not really sure what you want to achieve by showing some equations on top of your videos. In my opinion, if your goal is to make people "aware" of the mathematical part of the phenomenon you are explaining, then you must spend at least some time explaining the equation.

For example at 7:17 - what do v,ω and r represent? why does one equation have a + and the other one a -? what do these equations mean?

To someone familiar with the phenomenon or at least with the physics involved, these questions might seem straight forward, but to everyone else (like 99% of your audience I suppose) I am pretty sure they are not.

I once read (I believe it was a book by S. Hawking), that for every equation that you put in your book, your audience of readers is halved. I believe this is especially true if you don't explain what those equations actually mean, and why they are important to mention in the first place.

Let's be honest: math never looks good at first glance, the only way to make it just a tiny bit more interesting is to begin to understand it.

You repeatedly reference heat melting. You appear to be neglecting pressure melting. Take a thin copper wire (a single strand) and an ice cube. Hold the ends of the wire under tension, and press it against the cube. You'll be able to, slowly, press the copper wire all the way through the ice cube without cutting it in half. This isn't heat melting the ice, it is pressure, or at least that is how its been explained to me.
